metadata.case_name: Executor of Lakshmamma (Appellant) v. Respondent No. 1 (Widow of Narayana Iyengar)

facts.text: Annaji Iyengar died in July 1903 leaving adopted son (appellant), daughters Gundamma and Lakshmamma.
Annaji executed gift deed Ex. D on February 16, 1902, gifting items 1 and 2 jointly to Lakshmamma and Sadagopalachar.
Annaji executed will Ex. B2 on August 31, 1901, bequeathing hypothecation bonds worth Rs. 10,320 to Lakshmamma and Sadagopalachar with survivorship.
Sadagopalachar, husband of Lakshmamma, died in December 1908.
Sadagopalachar used Rs. 10,320 from Annaji's will to purchase immovable properties including items 3 and 4.
Lakshmamma and Sadagopalachar's son Narayana Iyengar died on January 14, 1944, without issue, leaving widow respondent 1.
Lakshmamma executed alleged will Ex. A on August 22, 1945, and died on September 26, 1945.
Will Ex. A disposed properties: life interest in items 1-2 to respondent 1, then to respondents 2-4 and 5; items 3-5 to respondents 2-5 with charges for legacies and charities.

Appellant filed suit O.S. No. 44 of 1946-47 in Subordinate Judge, Mysore, for declaration of Lakshmamma's ownership, validity of will, possession of items 3-5, life interest declaration for items 1-2, Rs. 2,106 past profits, future mesne profits.

Trial court (Subordinate Judge, Mysore, decree December 19, 1947) held Annaji's will genuine with survivorship; gift deed no survivorship; Lakshmamma half share in all properties; will genuine for half share; decreed half share possession items 3-5, Rs. 1050 profits, future enquiry, parties bear costs.

Respondent 1 appealed to Mysore High Court (R.A. No. 155 of 1947-48, judgment March 20, 1951): will not proved; no proof items 3-5 from bequest; Lakshmamma transferred interest to husband; suit dismissed.

Lakshmamma aged 64, ill with paralysis at Mandya, will executed there; appellant prepared draft, dictated to scribe Chokkanna (PW3), read to her, signed, attested by PW1 Krishnamurthy Rao, PW2 Narasimha Iyengar, registered same day; power of attorney Ex. EE also executed.
Narayana Iyengar sold properties exceeding his share.
Lakshmamma transferred interests in gift deed properties to Sadagopalachar.
Items 3-5 purchased by Sadagopalachar/Narayana with own funds, not from bequest.

legal_issues.text: Whether the will Ex. A executed by Lakshmamma on August 22, 1945, was duly and validly executed by her while in sound and disposing state of mind, understanding its contents.
Whether Lakshmamma had absolute title to the suit properties to make a will.

petitioner_arguments.text: Lakshmamma absolute owner via survivorship under gift deed Ex. D and Annaji's will Ex. B2; subsequent purchases from bequeathed funds; Narayana sold excess share; will Ex. A genuine, executed voluntarily in sound mind; supported by attesting witnesses, scribe, PW4.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Succession Act ss. 59, 63; Evidence Act ss. 67, 68

petitioner_arguments.text: Proof of signature and execution raises presumption of knowledge of contents; evidence satisfactory, no rebuttal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Surendra Nath Chatterji v. Jahnavi Charn Mukerji

respondent_arguments.text: No Annaji will or Rs.10,320 bequest; no survivorship in gift deed Ex. D; Lakshmamma transferred interests to Sadagopalachar; items 3-5 from own funds; Narayana absolute owner; Lakshmamma no title; will not genuine, not sound mind, machinations of appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Proof of wills requires signature, sound mind, understanding contents; suspicious circumstances (active role of beneficiary appellant, improbable dispositions to appellant's sons over grandchildren, elaborate argumentative preamble unnatural for testatrix, no clear prior instructions proof, discrepancies in witnesses) not removed by evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court justified in holding will not proved due to suspicious circumstances and unsatisfactory evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Propounder must discharge heavy onus where suspicious circumstances exist; appellant's prominent role, benefit to sons, unnatural exclusions suspicious.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Elaborate recitals in preamble artificial, not from testatrix instructions.

court_reasoning.text: High Court obiter on title issues not justified as will proof failure renders unnecessary; leave open.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Revenue entries/possession insufficient for title transfer or adverse possession proof.

holdings.text: Will must be proved like any document but with solemnity; propounder proves essentials, but suspicious circumstances require removal by clear evidence satisfying prudent mind/judicial conscience.
Execution surrounded by suspicious circumstances not removed; will not proved as last will of Lakshmamma.

precedents_cited.relevance: Onus on propounder to satisfy court; preparation/benefit by propounder excites suspicion.
Benefit and role in execution throws onus to show righteousness.
Suspicion not confined to propounder benefit; extends to circumstances exciting suspicion.
Chief beneficiary leading in execution must remove suspicion.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sarat Kumari Bibi v. Sakhi Chand
precedents_cited.relevance: Propounder must remove suspicions from court mind.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rash Mohini Dasi v. Umesh Chunder Biswas
precedents_cited.relevance: Manager's role in simple will suspicious if no independent intention.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shama Charn Kundu v. Khettromoni Dasi

precedents_cited.relevance: Solicitor beneficiary must satisfy onus; evidence examined.
Sound mind at instructions; execution if accepts as per instructions.
Reasonable scepticism, not incredulity; respect trial court credibility.

precedents_cited.case_name: Surendra Nath Chatterji v. Jahnavi Charn Mukerji
precedents_cited.relevance: Presumption from signature rebuttable by suspicions.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Proof of documents, signatures, handwriting, attestation.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Succession Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Sound mind for will; signing, attestation requirements.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's reversal of trial court's decree, holding appellant failed to prove due execution of Lakshmamma's will due to suspicious circumstances not removed; suit dismissed; other title issues left open.
outcome.costs: No orders as to costs mentioned.

key_quotes.text: "the onus probandi lies in every case upon the party propounding a will and he must satisfy the conscience of the court that the instrument so propounded is the last will of a free and capable testator."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Classic statement of onus from Barry v. Butlin.

key_quotes.text: If a party writes or prepares a will under which he takes a benefit, that is a circumstance that ought generally to excite the suspicion of the court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Suspicious circumstance due to propounder's role/benefit.

key_quotes.text: "where a will is charged with suspicion, the rules enjoin a reasonable scepticism, not an obdurate persistence in disbelief."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Harmes v. Hinkson; judicial approach to suspicions.
